ansible/roles/ceph-rgw/defaults/main.yml.message:
One issue here is that we end up with server lines like this:

server <host or IP>:port <host or IP>:port ..

Normally we would have this:

server host IP:port ...

Which means that we get the hostname in haproxy logs, but it does not need to resolve to the correct IP.

I can see two approaches which might make sense.

1. provide some or all of the raw haproxy server config

 ceph_rgw_hosts:
   - "host1 IP1:port"
   - "host2 IP2:port"

2. provide a list of dicts with all info

 ceph_rgw_hosts:
   - host: host1
     ip: host1
     port: port
   - host: host2
     ip: host2
     port: port
I personally see the list of dicts as a cleaner solution, but option 1) is less typing :)
any default we could have here?
Oops, meant to delete that comment. The beast API frontend defaults to 80 or 443, so I went with that. 6780 is our default for the HAProxy frontend.
is 6780 not a good default (for us)?
mention this should follow the ceph rgw's config as we are not in control of that (only follow what user tells us)

swift_account

(to match the ceph's config name for this)
I think you'd need to add the 'ssl' option to the config to get HAProxy to use 443. It could be done via the ceph_rgw_haproxy_healthcheck option, but I haven't tried it.

ceph-client/templates/bin/pool/_init.sh..message: The query only filters out active, not active+clean. I believe this is correct behavior, but this comment has me questioning if that is the intention.

ceph-client/values.yaml.message: This could be 'peering' or 'peered', but both of those indicate inactive PGs and probably shouldn't be considered acceptable.
Correct, both are checking. And they are absolutely acceptable in case of re-balancing. Maybe I should add some additional checks.

'Activating' also indicates that a PG is inactive. I wonder if there should be a third category of states that are acceptable temporarily but become critical after a certain amount of time. A PG that is activating, peering, or peered should be on its way to becoming active, but it isn't there yet. If it doesn't leave that state it should become critical.
I agree about third class of states (see my reply above)

"Activating," "creating," and "peering" aren't critical or acceptable states. They should be temporary, and PGs should leave these states and become active relatively quickly. If they don't, then these become critical states because the PG is stuck inactive and can't serve client I/O requests.

It seems like the logic here will simply fail a deployment if any of these states is encountered.

In my test setup I have 3 nodes labeled with 'dvr' and 1 node labeled with both 'dvr' and 'snat' - but for some reason on each of those 4 nodes l3 agent has dvr_snat mode. Not sure if it's a bug or some wrong config. l3 agent daemonset naming in pod list seems correct:

neutron-l3-agent-dvr-012d1698-59rs9
neutron-l3-agent-dvr-012d1698-nth42
neutron-l3-agent-dvr-012d1698-xrr9j
neutron-l3-agent-snat-a263e36a-n7q7v
Seems it's https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2005936 and I have to update helm infra.

I suggest to move all dvr related options to values-overrides/dvr.yaml like it is done for ldap in keystone https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm/blob/master/keystone/values_overrides/ldap.yaml

and left here only general values:networking:dvr:false

dvr enablement requires some changes in different places, so it is good practice to place them in one file, so when deployment engineer needs to enable some feature, all changes might be easily identified. I think you can consider values-overrides as some sort of documentation for features.
It will require additional changes (need to include dvr.yaml somewhere), which problem will it solve? What's wrong with having DVR here?

neutron/values_overrides/dvr.yaml.message: sorry to be ignorant here. But could you please provide some reference links explaining why this override work? Thank you.

Well, it's probably some issue with how you pass values/deploy neutron chart. Please verify that your values have this overrides section. Details on node label specific configuration can be found here: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm/blob/master/doc/source/devref/node-and-label-specific-configurations.rst

sorry, didn't get you: this overrides make 'agent_mode' in l3_agent.ini on nodes with openstack-compute-node label have 'dvr' value; on nodes with openstack-control-plane label have 'dvr_snat' value. configmap-etc doesn't do anything in regarding agent_mode.

no. in my opinion for dvr mode, l3-agent on different nodes should have different agent mode configured. I would like to know how this patch enables that? because seems that contents of l3_agent.ini in configmap-etc is fixed for every pod using it.

Hi, seems like `daemonset_overrides` will add a default deamonset https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/blob/74f3eb5824f7c52173088d63297f36769ed77a4e/helm-toolkit/templates/utils/_daemonset_overrides.tpl#L184. How can i disable it? I need to run l3 agent on control or compute node only.
ok, this is what i am asking： why this overrides will work that way? I still see agent_mode set to legacy in configmap-etc even though I set --values=dvr.yaml.
Sure, DVR configuration is described here https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/pike/admin/deploy-ovs-ha-dvr.html. Did I get you right?

rabbitmq/values.yaml.message: Would it make sense to define this in the endpoints section?  Maybe a services: key under .Values.endpoints.oslo_messaging.auth, and then consume the services: key to create the users.  The functionality should be the same, but it adheres to the standard of defining user credentials and vhost paths in the endpoints section

The idea is to keep the same structure like it already is in .Values.endpoint.oslo_messaging to use like a template
with the same structure/data in both places .Values.endpoints.oslo_messaging and .Values.conf.users.auth. In addition 
this approach drastically useful if values.yaml is generated by a metadata server or similar.

mariadb/templates/bin/_readiness.sh.tpl.message:
You'll have to adjust the readiness timeout and periodSeconds since the readiness probe can take much longer than those values.
  readiness:
    enabled: true
    params:
      initialDelaySeconds: 30
      periodSeconds: 30
      timeoutSeconds: 15

mariadb/values.yaml.message:
Period seconds needs to be longer than the actual duration of the probe, otherwise, k8s will kick off another probe before the first one is done - I don't think we would want that to happen.

Also, I don't think there is a need to change initialDelaySeconds, is there?

I'll set the periodSeconds = timeoutSeconds. Did not realize concurrent probes are triggred. 

I'll restore the initialDelaySeconds to : 30. No reason why I set to 60s.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Can we add a test which exercises this behavior?  It's apparent that this change doesn't break the status quo, since siblings are tested in zuul-jobs-test-tox.  But this looks like the sort of thing that would be easy to regress if we don't test.  Maybe we can add "-vv" to that job?

Since you're adding extra_args in a followup, if you wanted to use that facility then i think adding the test then (and verifying it based on the dependency chain) should be fine.

Technically the followup change does exercise this, because tox_extra_args defaults to "-vv" in the role currently. You're right though, a direct test would help safeguard against regressions in the event that the default value for it every changes to drop the "-vv" at some point. I'll see if I can figure out where would be a good place would be for that.

roles/tox/library/tox_install_sibling_pa.message: Looks like I may have to use normal strings since the line iterator below appears to return strings not bytes.
Oops, this is reused below for the configparser object, I'll need a different variable name.
I'm losing track of how to do backwards-compatible file I/O, but apparently open() doesn't have an encoding keyarg on 2.7!

I'll #noqa this since it's valid under Python 2.7 but we lint with 3.x where it isn't, and the AttributeError exception should not be raised on 3.2 or later where configparser gained the read_string() method.
... I don't think we need this workaround?
They're the ones which failed patchset #7, so also a debian-buster job apparently (I guess it was also defaulting to Python 2.7 as it raises the same errors).

This change failed various jobs for platforms where Ansible uses Python 2.7 (e.g. zuul-jobs-test-fetch-sphinx-tarball-centos-7), hence the various earlier patchsets fiddling with getting 2.7 working through all the new code. Maybe the intent is to not run this under 2.7, but in that case there are quite a few existing jobs which will need fixing I guess.

hrm, are they mostly centos-7?

We now have python3 installed on centos7 by default, so we could, it seems, switch the python-path in [1] and override.  that would make us python3 only?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/src/branch/master/nodepool/nodepool.yaml#L140
The Software factory CI seems to be indicating that this split(':') may return a single element in the result which results in [1] being an index out of bounds.

releasenotes/notes/seed-disable-snat-4d1.message: Maybe document what is the reason for the change?

It won't actively be disabled on upgrade - it would need to be disabled manually. The iptables rules are not persistent, so would disappear after a reboot. The sysctls for IP routing are persistent however, so your seed remains a router after upgrade.
Ok, I'll drop the upgrade: section and include it in a follow-up where I'll fix the rule persistency and sysctl disablement.

README.md.message:
I think this might confuse people: we recommend Ceph as a volume backend but not necessarily as a libvirt image backend. Our deployments use local qcow2 images most of the time and this is preferable because some instances might have databases with native replication - they do not need an underlying replicated storage.

I would instead say that "Ceph is a recommended Cinder volume backend".

I would call out that a better alternative to using this is the "boot from volume" functionality.

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/launch-instance-from-volume.html

Instead of replacing ephemeral storage with RBD for all VMs, only select VMs booted from volumes will have a root disk on an RBD image.
I'm wondering why saying "concurrent" here? I'm sure you don't mean we can use both at the same time, but is "concurrent" here an intrinsic property of Ceph?
Discussed offline: I'm wrong and it really means that two backends can be used at the same time. All good.
Discussed offline: not a typo, "cephx" is a thing.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e07bb310b674fb471a92edf3258e564f05534595/nova/virt/libvirt/volume/volume.py#L163-L169
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e07bb310b674fb471a92edf3258e564f05534595/nova/virt/libvirt/volume/nvme.py#L27-L63

I just commented in https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1945439/comments/6 - mainly there needs to be some way found that will make this work. Even for ffu we have 3 consecutive undercloud upgrades so the point to point upgrade still applies.

I am ok to make it non voting because it is blocking while we are waiting for a particular fix, but i think the discussion about removing this permanently needs to be had especially with the upgrades team.

manifests/profile/base/nova/libvirt.pp.message: "ro" as in "read-only"? wouldn't that be something more like 0444?

templates/nova/virtlogd.epp.message: "nope" for first proposal, "maybe" for second one. If we can avoid getting 10 logs in 100 different locations.....

No collision nor issues:
- podman supports mounting same volume in 2 distinct locations
- as said in the commit message, "This is possible since the swtpm log filename is composed of the instance
ID suffixed by "-swtpm.log", leading to a clear view."

guess we're all covered. This specific log might be configurable in the future, meaning we'll be able to drop that "clone" mount, but right now, its location is hardcoded....
there is /var/log/swtpm/libvirt/qemu and /var/log/libvirt/qemu which would be merged on the host path /var/log/containers/libvirt/qemu. I hope that doesn't create collisions?
or /var/log/containers/libvirt/swtpm please, to not produce duplicate bind-mount targets?

swift/common/wsgi.py.message: I don't really understand why the signature is like this - we don't seem to actually *use* args in _initrp
i guess there's no way for a run_server caller to modify this tho
it'd be better if this was in signature; or at least the doc string
isn't this the same global_conf that's already plumbed all the way down to loadapp?

Yup -- I was noticing that this feels suspicious, too. Either this shouldn't pass global_conf, or we should start passing it down below when spawning workers. But IDK which, and didn't want to get into it right now.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Are you using the user_enabled_mask option? This setting should not be 544 when it gets to the shadow backend, it should already have been converted to a boolean by the ldap driver.

keystone/identity/shadow_backends/sql.py.message: You cannot just assume that this will always be true. For LDAP specifically, there is a whole series of configuration options about how to figure out if a user should be enabled or not. https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/d2b5550214cecd8a753253066d61e3419e76e952/keystone/conf/ldap.py#L159-L202

Hi Kristi,

Thanks for your comments! submit the new patch for it. Since the enabled value has been processed by functionality _ldap_res_to_model, if it still in integer format, I think it is true. I think it also keep consistent with using sqlalchemy 1.1.x which take integer as bool True.
This still misses Kristi's point about assuming whether the user is enabled or not. It cannot be hardcoded to True, it needs to read the existing value and convert it appropriately.
This is not a good use of try/except. This should use if/else logic to check the value and set it conditionally, not use this goto-style jumping logic.
This still needs to account for the case that new_user_dict['enabled'] is 0, i.e., NOT enabled.
Thanks for your explanation! Will fix in next patch.
Sorry, I still confused why 0 means not enabled. After ldap driver, this value should be real bool, like true or false. or integer if no  user_enabled_mask option used. Why integer 0 means disable?

There are cases where the deployer can explicitly tell keystone to use an alternative form for determining if the user is enabled. It becomes a comparison against an int of 0 or 1 (0 being disabled) which is not a true python boolean even though it evaluates to "False" [in most cases]. Blindly setting to "True" if it is any digit is incorrect and may cause users to be "enabled" incorrectly.
This would need to use else, otherwise str(0).isdigit() still evaluates to True and the enabled attribute is overwritten. You could also just cast the value directly with bool().
Thanks for comments! In fact, if works here since 0 has been translated to False, so it would not an integer anymore. But it looks a little confuse here, I will update to else.

zuul/nodepool.py.message: I guess we weren't actually taking advantage of the in defaults anywhere for these?
Right, this is deep enough in the startup that we'd get exceptions trying to test it if so.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I made no guarantees about getting rid of *all* of them :P

swift/container/backend.py.message: this isn't obvious to me (maybe the cylomatic complexity?) - and I feel like this "stale on-disk file brain" problem can happen essentially anywhere?

So we have a similar self.get_brokers()[0] in find_shard_ranges(), but there we should be pretty safe; we should have recently created the new DB file and not even started cleaving, so nothing should touch the big DB.

Thinking about it a bit, once we've actually recorded that final shard as being cleaved, we should *only* be looking to the old DB for stats; I *think* this might be mostly sufficient. *Maybe* we need to worry a little about a listing request for the end of the namespace coming in, too, but it'd need a wider window to be a problem.

I agree that the logic's become a bit hard to follow -- I was hoping that the early returns would maybe help, but idk, it's a bit of a mess :-(

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I'd say it's just a temporary solution to fix the issue, we will need to create additional Dockerfile with clusterctl vO.3.x installed to have backwards compatibility as described here https://hackmd.io/QiEksO4fRk-MnBjwBFaAkQ#UPD-Alexey-O, since we can't rely on old quay.io sha tag permanently.

https://github.com/airshipit/airshipctl/issues/647

Ruslan, feel free to add the part about the additional docker files if you would like to loop that into the issue. If Alexey is already working on that, I figured these two issues could be handled separately.

> I'd say it's just a temporary solution to fix the issue, we will need to create additional Dockerfile with clusterctl vO.3.x installed to have backwards compatibility as described here https://hackmd.io/QiEksO4fRk-MnBjwBFaAkQ#UPD-Alexey-O, since we can't rely on old quay.io sha tag permanently.

I will open a new issue to update this

zuul/driver/github/githubreporter.py.message: I think this is too simple as we have a lot more job results than success and failure (e..g. there is LOST, NODE_FAILURE, SKIPPED, ...)  and not all of them indicate a failure.

The inital motivation is to quickly identify the failed jobs (i assumed all non-success jobs), so I only selected two types of emojis. 
I was also thinking about select a emoji for each type, but not sure if it is necessary. 
How about a compromise: introduce 3 types of emoji: Success/Fail/Other, the "Other" type can be indicated with a ":warning:" (https://github.com/ikatyang/emoji-cheat-sheet/blob/master/README.md)?

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think you need:

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/openstack-armada-app/+/809276
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/fault/+/806046

zuul/driver/sql/sqlconnection.py.message: Good point, this was copy-pasta from code that didn't anticipate multiple actors.
Should you return a min value of 0 here just in case the clocks get skewed away from each other?
Correct.  We could get rid of it.
This code doesn't appear to be used anymore?

For posterity:
* list comprehension is a little faster than filter(lambda) (probably not enough to worry about in most cases)
* filter(None) is *much faster* than list comprehension, but filters out 0 which would be wrong here.  Worth using in other cases where it would be correct.
This could be replaced with https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#filter but is equivalent. Not sure if filter might have a quicker internal implementation thoughl

filter/map have been available in Python since 1.5.2, at least.  I remember when list comprehensions were touted as far superior for readability.  Here's a blast from the past: 

  https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/python-cookbook/0596001673/ch01s11.html

Anyway, it probably suffices to say I'm aware of filter and this was a deliberate choice.  We can all handle reading both forms, and we probably don't need to nitpick it?

Huh I vastly prefer the functional methods because they have well defined behaviors. But I can understand if others prefer comprehensions because they are more explicitly written out.

I only mentioned it here because I wasn't sure of the performance equivalence (they are functionally equivalent). Didn't meant to nitpick but noticed since sum was used below.
My thought was to have this object deal consistently with integers rather than have an outlier here.
We convert this back to a float when we use it. Would it be better to return a float here and not bother with the translation in the scheduler?

zuul/driver/sql/sqlreporter.py.message: As mentioned on a previous patchset do we need to guard against negative elapsed times? We know it is at least 0?
It would be good to add that here, yes.
I don't think this method is used.
Probably not, I can remove it.

zuul/lib/times.py.message: This appears to be our stop signal. Should we break instead of continuing?

Well, self.running should be false and it'll exit.  We're not taking advantage of it now, but I think of the None queue item as just a signal to get out of the 'get' call.  There's no other signal but 'stop' now, but there could be.
Maybe?  But duration=0 builds probably have something wrong with them anyway.

Should this be:

  if x.duration is not None

?
I brought it up due to our testing of any() and list comprehensions previously. Don't feel super strongly about it.

cinder/objects/volume.py.message: It's the first time I see bitwise operators in cinder code.

Since Sofia pointed this out, I wonder if there's any point in using the union function here instead of the operator.  It takes an iterable, and you wouldn't have to convert obj_extra_fields to a set before doing the union.

The test below, test_enforcer_understands_system_scope_creds_dict, will cover both code paths now.
For the other checks of the key/value mapping, the above test, test_enforcer_consolidates_context_attributes_with_creds, covers that case.

Again, if we still need python2, should we also have this for python2?

Does this version still work?  It's over 3 years and several versions behind. I'm concerned that it may suddenly stop working, although I suppose if it works now, we can continue to use it until it stops working.
This can probably be uplifted to a more recent version in a subsequent patch, but in general it does still work as the build job still works.

zuul/lib/yamlutil.py.message: I'm not really a fan of monkeypatching for this.  Let's just do something more straightforward, even if it's a bit more verbose.  It will be easier to read and maintain.
My two cents: make the parameter 'ignore_aliases' explicit with default value False would be more clear for the function support.

As written, the calling convention for this method is very unclear.  ignore_aliases is a required argument if any further positional arguments without default values are going to be supplied (and since we accept them, we should assume they may be).

ansible_unsafe_dump(inventory, ignore_aliases=True) is valid
ansible_unsafe_dump(inventory, foo, ignore_aliases=True) is invalid

That's very confusing.  Let's do something more straightforward.  Here are the choices I think would be okay (with the most preferable first):

1) kwargs.pop() -- it is simple and doesn't rely on any special understanding of the function signature
2) (data, *args, ignore_aliases=False, **kwargs) -- behaves the same way, but maintainers may blink a few times at seeing *args and *kwargs separated like that.
3) (data, ignore_aliases, *args, **kwargs) -- the positional equivalent of #2.  This breaks compatibility with the similar safe_dump methods, but is at least explicit.

ignore_aliases will pull from the positional args list, not the keyword args list, so this is not equivalent to my suggestion.  

You could put it between *args and **kwargs.  I'm not a fan of that, and we haven't done that anywhere else -- mostly because the whole "args, kwargs" pattern is so well set.

Or you could use kwargs.pop, which I think is pretty clear.

I think the main point of your suggestion is to define explicitly the class AnsibleUnsafeDumperWithoutAliases instead of dynamically adding the ignore_aliases.

Why shouldn't we put ignore_aliases parameter (with default value) in positional list?
Now I understand the point, I have uploaded a new patch which reverted it to your original change.

This is right as you do not want to run this job on a stable branch. If I understand correctly this test with ceph from source and only meant for master gate, right?

If so, then 'branches: master' is good guard for that in case we forget to remove this while new stable branches are cut. and if it exists in stable too then also I do not think it will cause any issue.

If we remove this branch variant then yes you should make sure you remove it from stable branch to avoid it running there.

stx/toCOPY/lat-tool/lat/latd.message: shouldn't we check that the task is stopped before starting a clean?
I agree. Thanks for pointing it out. Update it in next version of review.

stx/toCOPY/lat-tool/lat/volume.py.message: This messaging scheme doesn't look safe if two concurrent messages/commands are in flight at once.  Is it possible to have two concurrent messages, are is that being prevented somewhere that I'm not seeing?

In latc, we have:
    channel.send_message_to_server(msg)
    smsg = channel.get_server_message()

So unless the latc process gets response from server, it blocks there.

We are not supposed to have multiple latc processes.
Because the original design for the stx builder container is: one user, one stx builder.
So there should be no multiple latc processes running unless the user wants to deliberately mess things up by running something like 'latc xxx &; latc xxx'.
Qi can add some flock check to ensure at most one latc process is running if you think it's necessary.
If it blocks, I think we are safe as far as concurrency is concerned.

This class includes not only common parameters but also service specific parameters. For example log_filters is supposed to be defined differently and I doubt that some parameters like ovs_timeout is used on all moduels.

manifests/compute/libvirt/services.pp.message: Here enable_modular_libvirt_daemons is configurable but for the other modules, it is not.

We should check $virtlog_service_name .

Also, could you double check that this dependency is corret for module services ? Don't we need dependency against livirtd service?

> We should check $virtlog_service_name .
> 
yes. sure
> Also, could you double check that this dependency is corret for module services ? Don't we need dependency against livirtd service?
No, we can't check against libvirtd service, because either deployment have monolithic libvirtd daemon or modular daemons which provides functionality as libvirtd daemon.
For info re modular daemons is here [1].

[1] https://libvirt.org/daemons.html
This should point resource name thus hard-coded 'virtlogd' should be used. Also, it might be more simple to add require => Package['libvirt'] when declaring a service resource.
This looks like a duplicate of L131.
libvirt package resource is not declared when libvirt_service_name is false. Maybe it'd be better to put this into the top if block.
This dependency would fail if virtlog_service_name is not defined, because 'virtlogd' service resource is not declared. we should ensure that virtlogd_service_name is defined.
Do we still need the base libvirt service when modular daemons are used ? This looks conflicting with the change in nova::compute::libvirt which disables logging options when modular_libvirt is true.

Do we expect both modular services and the single libvirt service are provided by libvirt rpm in a future libvirt package ? If so, we should stop libvirt service here instead of skipping the resource.
Can we name this as libvirt_service_ensure_real ?
IIUC we need a dependency for modular daemon here.
This should be updated as well.
To follow the existing implementation, package should be installed only when service name is defined.
This should be updated to point the sub package.
Use Service<| name == 'virtlogd' |> instead, to avoid missing resource error when virtlog service name is undef.
